title: UK travel trade praises Vietnam's visa waiver
text:
UK travel trade praises Vietnam's visa waiver 1 July 2015 | By Edward Robertson Save 
Removing the visa requirement to Vietnam will open the country to more late sales, stopovers and beach tourism, operators believe. 
Vietnam withdrew the fee across Europe at short notice last week following lobbying from operators, saving UK visitors who obtain it through a third party around £100 and those who bought it independently a £54 fee. The waiver applies to British nationals for stays of up to 15 days and applies until June 30 next year. 
Asia specialist Insider Journeys has cut £100 off small group tours in Indochina that include Vietnam for bookings made by July 31. 
“The vast majority of our clients fit into that 15-day validity,” said Lesley Wright, the operator’s general manager, commercial. “It would be lovely if it was 30-day, but we will see the greater impact from travellers looking for a two-week journey.” 
Wright said securing visas for late sales had been a problem, with letters of authorisation needed for visa on arrival. “I’ve waited up to an hour, it’s not a great way to start your holiday,” she said. 
She added: “This also opens the door to a three or four-day stopover on the way to Australia and makes Vietnam more attractive as a beach destination.” 
The suspension of the visa fee will be followed by the upgrading of Vietnam Airlines’ flights from Heathrow to Ho Chi Minh and Hanoi to a new Boeing 787-9 this summer. 
“This will also really put Vietnam up there,” Wright said. 
James Mundy, InsideAsia Tours’ PR and marketing manager, said removing the visa would have an impact: “Although it was not a particularly troublesome or costly process in the first place, it will remove mental barriers to travelling to Vietnam and allow people to travel trouble-free to Vietnam.” 
Mundy added that exemption meant all of InsideAsia’s tours could now be visited without having to go through lengthy visa processes before travel. 
“Vietnam and Japan are visa-free on arrival, Cambodia and Laos are simple and cheap on arrival into the country and Burma can be arranged with a straightforward online e-visa.” 
Laurence Hicks, managing director at Wendy Wu Tours, added: “This is a move towards recognition that UK and EU visitors are undeniably valuable to Vietnam’s tourism economy.”
